prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Faintest galaxy
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
measurement of the 1.3 mm continuum flux and extent (along the semi-major axis) for the galaxy with the faintest predicted surfce brightness in the mass-complete volume-limited sample of 21 spiral galaxies.
G6019161

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to detect and resolve dust continuum emission in our source galaxies. Therefore, we have chosen the correlator set-up to maximize bandwidth and thus achievable sensitivity. As discussed in the science case, both band 6 and 7 are suitbale for our purposes. Given the greater ease of scheduling for band 6 we adopt it for our investigation.

The choice of array(angular ressolution and LAS) is determined by the need to have a resolution of 2*r_eff plus the need to encompass linear scales of 6*r_eff, which correspond to the observed extent of dust in local universe spirals. In making the translation from an optically measured reef to a dust scale, we adopt the results of Xilouris et al. (1999). Furthermore, the choice of 0.8" angular resolution will allow us to select galaxies only resolved along the semi-major axis - boosting surface brightness - while ensuring that no severe inclination bias is incurred. Finally, the relatively compact array configuration also benefits overall sensitivity.

For the purpose of constraining the dust content and distribution in normal main sequence spiral galaxies at z~0.-7 we require a representative sampling of the full distribution of these spirals in the stellar mass - stellar mass surface density plane as realized by our mass complete sample of 21 spirals galaxies. These galaxies are all drawn from the zCOSMOS (Lilly et al. 2007) field, hence lie within a 2x2 deg^2 field. To optimize efficiency by minimizing overheads and calibration time, we have grouped the 21 galaxies in 4 categories according to their predicted 1.3mm surface brightness (estimated as explained below). For each of the categories of expected surface brightness we have created a science goal combining the the galaxies in the respective category and assigning each a pointing.
For the galaxy predicted to be the faintest we expect a surface brightness of 0.05 mJy/beam, thus, to ensure a S/N of 3 we require a sensitivity of 16.5 muJy as specified. Due to the long integration time required on source, this galaxy is alone in its science goal
-Surface brightness estimation-- We have used the relation between dust mass and stellar mass for morphologically selected spiral galaxies in the local universe (Grootes et al. 2013), in combination with the available stellar mass measurements (Mobasher et al., 2007) to estimate the dust mass of the galaxy. We subsequently scale this estimate by a factor of 3 to account for the redshift evolution of the dust mass in galaxies. This factor of 3 is that by which the dust- to-stellar mass ratio is found to evolve out to redshift 0.3 (Dunne et al. 2011), and we take it as a conservative estimate of the evolution to z~0.7. In estimating the detectability of our sources we calculate the surface brightness (in mJy/beam; accounting for the redshift dependent surface brightness dimming) rather than integrated fluxes, accounting for the fact that with 0.8" angular resolution the galaxies are resolved (as desired, cf. fig. 2). To predict the surface brightness of our sources we use the dust model of Weingartner & Draine (2001) with a modified blackbody spectrum with a spectral index of 2 and a characteristic temperature of 18K, and make use of the known optical size and orientation to convert integrated submm fluxes into surface brightnesses. In order to increase the effective surface brightness, while maintaining the ability to resolve the distribution of dust, we preferentially select galaxies which are only resolved along the semi-major axis. We note that, both in our predictions and proposed analysis, we make use of the Weingartner & Draine dust model for Milky Way dust, which has proven to be widely successful in applications in the local universe. It is possible that this model will not apply for cosmologically distant galaxies, however, since the dust mass estimates of Dunne et al. (2011) for z=0.3 galaxies are also based on this model, our detectability estimates implicitly take into account any shift in submm grain emissivity from z=0 to z=0.3.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Low surface brightness galaxies
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Measurement of total 1.3mm flux and (where possible) extent for the 7 spiral galaxies with low values of predicted surface brightness in the mass-complete volume limited parent sample of 21 spiral galaxies.
G6004753 G6001171 G6024319 G6009669 G6002160 G6002355 G6000986

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to detect and resolve dust continuum emission in our source galaxies. Therefore, we have chosen the correlator set-up to maximize bandwidth and thus achievable sensitivity. As discussed in the science case, both band 6 and 7 are suitbale for our purposes. Given the greater ease of scheduling for band 6 we adopt it for our investigation.

The choice of array is determined by the need to have a resolution of 2*r_eff plus the need to encompass linear scales of 6*r_eff, which correspond to the observed extent of dust in local universe spirals. In making the translation from an optically measured reef to a dust scale, we adopt the results of Xilouris et al. (1999). Furthermore, the choice of 0.8" angular resolution will allow us to select galaxies onlz resolved along the semi-major axis - boosting surface brightness - while ensuring that no severe inclination bias is incurred. Finally, the realtively compact array configurastion also benefits the overall sensitivity.

For the purpose of constraining the dust content and distribution in normal main sequence spiral galaxies at z~0.-7 we require a representative sampling of the full distribution of these spirals in the stellar mass - stellar mass surface density plane as realized by our mass complete sample of 21 spirals galaxies. These galaxies are all drawn from the zCOSMOS (Lilly et al. 2007) field, hence lie within a 2x2 deg^2 field. To optimize efficiency by minimizing overheads and calibration time, we have grouped the 21 galaxies in 4 categories according to their predicted 1.3mm surface brightness (estimated as explained below). For each of the categories of expected surface brightness we have created a science goal combining the the galaxies in the respective category and assigning each a pointing.
For the 7 galaxies in the low surface brightness catagory we predicted the surface brightness to be between 0.0575 mJy/beam and 0.12 mJy/beam. To ensure a S/N of 3 we require a sensitivity of 19.0 muJy as specified.
-?Surface brightness estimation-?-? We have used the relation between dust mass and stellar mass for morphologically selected spiral galaxies in the local universe (Grootes et al. 2013), in combination with the available stellar mass measurements (Mobasher et al., 2007) to estimate the dust mass of the galaxy. We subsequently scale this estimate by a factor of 3 to account for the redshift evolution of the dust mass in galaxies. This factor of 3 is that by which the dust- to-stellar mass ratio is found to evolve out to redshift 0.3 (Dunne et al. 2011), and we take it as a conservative estimate of the evolution to z~0.7. In estimating the detectability of our sources we calculate the surface brightness (in mJy/beam; accounting for the redshift dependent surface brightness dimming) rather than integrated fluxes, accounting for the fact that with 0.8" angular resolution the galaxies are resolved (as desired, cf. fig. 2). To predict the surface brightness of our sources we use the dust model of Weingartner & Draine (2001) with a modified blackbody spectrum with a spectral index of 2 and a characteristic temperature of 18K, and make use of the known optical size and orientation to convert integrated submm fluxes into surface brightnesses. In order to increase the effective surface brightness, while maintaining the ability to resolve the distribution of dust, we preferentially select galaxies which are only resolved along the semi-major axis. We note that, both in our predictions and proposed analysis, we make use of the Weingartner & Draine dust model for Milky Way dust, which has proven to be widely successful in applications in the local universe. It is possible that this model will not apply for cosmologically distant galaxies, however, since the dust mass estimates of Dunne et al. (2011) for z=0.3 galaxies are also based on this model, our detectability estimates implicitly take into account any shift in submm grain emissivity from z=0 to z=0.3.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Intermediate surfce brightness galaxies
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Measurement of total 1.3mm flux and (where possible) extent for the 5 spiral galaxies with intermediate values of predicted surface brightness in the mass complete parent sample of 21 spiral galaxies.
G6003889 G6005263 G6003821 G6002415 G6020308

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to detect and resolve dust continuum emission in our source galaxies. Therefore, we have chosen the correlator set-up to maximize bandwidth and thus achievable sensitivity. As discussed in the science case, both band 6 and 7 are suitbale for our purposes. Given the greater ease of scheduling for band 6 we adopt it for our investigation.

The choice of array is determined by the need to have a resolution of 2*r_eff plus the need to encompass linear scales of 6*r_eff, which correspond to the observed extent of dust in local universe spirals. In making the translation from an optically measured reef to a dust scale, we adopt the results of Xilouris et al. (1999). Furthermore, the choice of 0.8" angular resolution will allow us to select galaxies onlz resolved along the semi-major axis - boosting surface brightness - while ensuring that no severe inclination bias is incurred. Finally, the realtively compact array configurastion also benefits the overall sensitivity.

For the purpose of constraining the dust content and distribution in normal main sequence spiral galaxies at z~0.-7 we require a representative sampling of the full distribution of these spirals in the stellar mass - stellar mass surface density plane as realized by our mass complete sample of 21 spirals galaxies. These galaxies are all drawn from the zCOSMOS (Lilly et al. 2007) field, hence lie within a 2x2 deg^2 field. To optimize efficiency by minimizing overheads and calibration time, we have grouped the 21 galaxies in 4 categories according to their predicted 1.3mm surface brightness (estimated as explained below). For each of the categories of expected surface brightness we have created a science goal combining the the galaxies in the respective category and assigning each a pointing.
For the 5 galaxies in the intermediate surface brightness catagory we predict surface brightnesses between 0.12 mJy/beam and 0.15 mJy/beam. To ensure a S/N of 3 we require a sensitivity of 40 muJy as specified.
-Surface brightness estimation-- We have used the relation between dust mass and stellar mass for morphologically selected spiral galaxies in the local universe (Grootes et al. 2013), in combination with the available stellar mass measurements (Mobasher et al., 2007) to estimate the dust mass of the galaxy. We subsequently scale this estimate by a factor of 3 to account for the redshift evolution of the dust mass in galaxies. This factor of 3 is that by which the dust- to-stellar mass ratio is found to evolve out to redshift 0.3 (Dunne et al. 2011), and we take it as a conservative estimate of the evolution to z~0.7. In estimating the detectability of our sources we calculate the surface brightness (in mJy/beam; accounting for the redshift dependent surface brightness dimming) rather than integrated fluxes, accounting for the fact that with 0.8" angular resolution the galaxies are resolved (as desired, cf. fig. 2). To predict the surface brightness of our sources we use the dust model of Weingartner & Draine (2001) with a modified blackbody spectrum with a spectral index of 2 and a characteristic temperature of 18K, and make use of the known optical size and orientation to convert integrated submm fluxes into surface brightnesses. In order to increase the effective surface brightness, while maintaining the ability to resolve the distribution of dust, we preferentially select galaxies which are only resolved along the semi-major axis. We note that, both in our predictions and proposed analysis, we make use of the Weingartner & Draine dust model for Milky Way dust, which has proven to be widely successful in applications in the local universe. It is possible that this model will not apply for cosmologically distant galaxies, however, since the dust mass estimates of Dunne et al. (2011) for z=0.3 galaxies are also based on this model, our detectability estimates implicitly take into account any shift in submm grain emissivity from z=0 to z=0.3.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: brightest galaxies
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Measurement of total 1.3mm flux and (where possible) extent for the 8 spiral galaxies with highest values of predicted surface brightness in the mass complete parent sample of 21 spiral galaxies.
G6004474 G6025801 G6002062 G6005155 G6003028 G6000573 G6002182 G6026033

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to detect and resolve dust continuum emission in our source galaxies. Therefore, we have chosen the correlator set-up to maximize bandwidth and thus achievable sensitivity. As discussed in the science case, both band 6 and 7 are suitbale for our purposes. Given the greater ease of scheduling for band 6 we adopt it for our investigation.

The choice of array is determined by the need to have a resolution of 2*r_eff plus the need to encompass linear scales of 6*r_eff, which correspond to the observed extent of dust in local universe spirals. In making the translation from an optically measured reef to a dust scale, we adopt the results of Xilouris et al. (1999). Furthermore, the choice of 0.8" angular resolution will allow us to select galaxies onlz resolved along the semi-major axis - boosting surface brightness - while ensuring that no severe inclination bias is incurred. Finally, the realtively compact array configurastion also benefits the overall sensitivity.

For the purpose of constraining the dust content and distribution in normal main sequence spiral galaxies at z~0.-7 we require a representative sampling of the full distribution of these spirals in the stellar mass - stellar mass surface density plane as realized by our mass complete sample of 21 spirals galaxies. These galaxies are all drawn from the zCOSMOS (Lilly et al. 2007) field, hence lie within a 2x2 deg^2 field. To optimize efficiency by minimizing overheads and calibration time, we have grouped the 21 galaxies in 4 categories according to their predicted 1.3mm surface brightness (estimated as explained below). For each of the categories of expected surface brightness we have created a science goal combining the the galaxies in the respective category and assigning each a pointing.
For the 8 in the brightest galaxies catagory we predict surface brightnesses > 0.17 mJy/beam. To ensure a S/N of 3 we require a sensitivity of 55 muJy as specified.
Fundametally the chained observations for the low intermediate and bright galaxies are not fundamentally different in their setup, thus, we surmise, that efficiency might be further improved in Phase 2 in collaboration with ALMA experts.
-Surface brightness estimation-- We have used the relation between dust mass and stellar mass for morphologically selected spiral galaxies in the local universe (Grootes et al. 2013), in combination with the available stellar mass measurements (Mobasher et al., 2007) to estimate the dust mass of the galaxy. We subsequently scale this estimate by a factor of 3 to account for the redshift evolution of the dust mass in galaxies. This factor of 3 is that by which the dust- to-stellar mass ratio is found to evolve out to redshift 0.3 (Dunne et al. 2011), and we take it as a conservative estimate of the evolution to z~0.7. In estimating the detectability of our sources we calculate the surface brightness (in mJy/beam; accounting for the redshift dependent surface brightness dimming) rather than integrated fluxes, accounting for the fact that with 0.8" angular resolution the galaxies are resolved (as desired, cf. fig. 2). To predict the surface brightness of our sources we use the dust model of Weingartner & Draine (2001) with a modified blackbody spectrum with a spectral index of 2 and a characteristic temperature of 18K, and make use of the known optical size and orientation to convert integrated submm fluxes into surface brightnesses. In order to increase the effective surface brightness, while maintaining the ability to resolve the distribution of dust, we preferentially select galaxies which are only resolved along the semi-major axis. We note that, both in our predictions and proposed analysis, we make use of the Weingartner & Draine dust model for Milky Way dust, which has proven to be widely successful in applications in the local universe. It is possible that this model will not apply for cosmologically distant galaxies, however, since the dust mass estimates of Dunne et al. (2011) for z=0.3 galaxies are also based on this model, our detectability estimates implicitly take into account any shift in submm grain emissivity from z=0 to z=0.3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA band 6 surface photometry of 21 spiral galaxies at z$\,\sim\,$0.7 with HST imaging, carefully selected from the HST COSMOS and zCOSMOS surveys. The ALMA maps will determine the generic relation between face-on stellar surface mass density and dust surface density, as well as the relation of the relative scale lengths of dust and optical emissivity in spiral galaxies at these redshifts. Applying methods we have proven for large samples of local Universe spiral galaxies, we will apply this relation to the parent population of COSMOS galaxies with known morphologies, sizes, stellar masses and ellipticies, to identify a suitable geometric model to deattenuate the rest frame broad-band and nebular UV-optical emission from intermediate redshift galaxies using radiation transfer techniques. This will result in a general and widely applicable tool for use in a range of investigations into processes controlling the growth of stellar mass in spiral galaxies.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomical Institute of the Romanian Academy
